snippet: The rise of surrogacy links wealthy couples with poor women, in a murky world of online brokers, dubious private clinics and expensive trips to foreign countries.
abstract: China, facing rising infertility, recent relaxation of one-child-per-family policy and cultural imperative to have children, is experiencing a boom in underground surrogacy; experts say black market surrogacy produces well over 10,000 births a year, and link rise to wealthier, better-educated Chinese couples waiting until their late 30s to start a family, trend that makes it harder to conceive.

byline.original: By IAN JOHNSON and CAO LI

lead_paragraph: The rise of surrogacy links wealthy couples with poor women, in a murky world of online brokers, dubious private clinics and expensive trips to foreign countries.

headline.main: China Experiences a Booming Underground Market in Surrogate Motherhood
headline.print_headline: China Experiences a Booming Underground Market in Child Surrogacy
